title: Current Projects
text: Carotenoid absorbance spectra change as they are cleaved by Carotenoid Cleavage Dioxygenases (CCDs) like Beta-Carotene Oxygenase 2 (BCO2). Making use of this fact and my computational expertise, I am working with other members of the von Lintig Lab to develop a high-throughput enzyme activity assay. This assay should allow us to characterize the function of CCDs more easily and consistently. This assay should also directly enable enzyme kinetics and mechanistic analysis elaborating on previous findings.

title: Current Projects
text:
BCO2 Structural Projects
Currently, I am working on two separate structural biochemistry projects in the Johannes von Lintig Lab. Both projects relate to the function of BCO2, an essential enzyme in carotenoid homeostasis.

BCO2 Structural Determination
BCO2 is a membrane-associated mitochondrial enzyme that is difficult to purify in a consistent and functional form. I developed a new protein purification protocol that relies extensively on micellar manipulation and an optimized affinity chromatography setup to substantially increase yield, purity, and stability of purified murine and human BCO2. This enabled various previous findings that I have presented or will present at national conferences.
Currently, working together with the Chakrapani Lab, we are attempting to determine an empirical structure of murine BCO2 using CryoEM.


Rational Enzyme Design
Perhaps the most ambitious project I’ve worked on yet, my current aim here is to produce a broadly-specific synthetic CCD that will allow for the flexible production of particular carotenoid cleavage products. This work expands from a serendipitous discovery of a point mutation in BCO2 that results in the production of only the first cleaved carotenoid product. Working from predicted structural models and sequence alignments, along with a few key structural insights, my aims are to:

Introduce the substrate promiscuity of BCO2 into BCO1
Alter key parts of the enzyme to shift substrate positioning in catalysis
Ultimately, produce a synthetic, adjustable CCD for specific apo-carotenoid production

Welcome to my website!
My name is Alexander Krammer. I am a fourth-year undergraduate student studying Biochemistry and Systems Biology at Case Western Reserve University.
I am currently applying to medical school and aspire to become a physician. In working towards that goal, I have spent a great deal of time volunteering at the Louis Stokes VA Medical Center and have engaged in research that is outlined in more detail on the “Projects” page. I have also spent a considerable amount of time engaged in leadership and other service activities, and will continue to work as the Senior Teaching Assistant for Organic Chemistry.
Please feel free to explore this site and contact me via email if you have any questions or would like to discuss potential projects.

title: Photography
text:
As a wizard and scholar of Middle-earth, I have been studying the magic of the natural world for centuries. Through my self-portraits, I aim to capture the essence of my own being and reflect on my own journey through time. Each photograph is a reflection of my own experiences and emotions. Through my photography, I hope to offer a glimpse into my life as a scholar and adventurer, and inspire others to reflect on their own journeys through the world.
